diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,233 @@
+#pragma once
+
+#include <torch/data/detail/data-shuttle.h>
+#include <torch/data/detail/sequencers.h>
+#include <torch/data/options.h>
+#include <torch/data/samplers/random.h>
+
+#include <torch/csrc/utils/memory.h>
+#include <torch/csrc/utils/variadic.h>
+
+#include <ATen/Error.h>
+#include <ATen/optional.h>
+
+#include <cstddef>
+#include <thread>
+#include <type_traits>
+#include <utility>
+
+namespace torch {
+namespace data {
+template <
+    typename DatasetType,
+    typename SamplerType = samplers::RandomSampler<>>
+class DataLoader {
body: Hmm this actually works very differently than Python data loaders, and I don't think it's a good thing. In Python, `DataLoader` is almost free to create, because it's really a holder for some options. It's the iterator that does all the threading, and actually deals with loading the data. This has a number of benefits, including the fact that you have very clear bounds when iterator objects are used, can have multiple of those running in parallel, and every one gets an independent instance of sampler.

In Python, DataLoader is almost free to create, because it's really a holder for some options. It's the iterator that does all the threading, and actually deals with loading the data. This has a number of benefits, including the fact that you have very clear bounds when iterator objects are used, can have multiple of those running in parallel, and every one gets an independent instance of sampler.
body_text: Hmm this actually works very differently than Python data loaders, and I don't think it's a good thing. In Python, DataLoader is almost free to create, because it's really a holder for some options. It's the iterator that does all the threading, and actually deals with loading the data. This has a number of benefits, including the fact that you have very clear bounds when iterator objects are used, can have multiple of those running in parallel, and every one gets an independent instance of sampler.
